Activities.Author: Tufts STOMP
Activities.Description: Students use simple machines and Lego programming to build a Rube Goldberg machine

Activities.Subject: Computer Science

Activities.Description: Students build and program a robot that uses something other than wheels to move

Activities.Subject: Computer Science

Activities.Description: Students design and fabricate their own name tag

Subject: Math
Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Data in computers is stored and transmitted as a series of zeros and ones. How can we represent words and numbers using just these two symbols?

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Teacher asks students a series of questions about their physical differences to help them form a "Human Tree Diagram"

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Students experience the specific/ literal nature of programming languages

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Raise awareness of human interface design issues by having students design a chocolate factory

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Hold a competition between a human and a programmed piece of paper

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Description: This activity aims to stimulate discussion on the question of whether computers can exhibit “intelligence
” or are ever likely to do so in the future.

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Use a story and fictitious problem to introduce the need for a sorting algorithm

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Learn about encryption in a historical context and practice encoding a message

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: This activity illustrates a situation in which information is shared without personal information being revealed

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Demonstrates how computers store pictures using numbers

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: Use a magic trick to show to detect and correct data corruption

Subject: Computer Science
Math
English
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: This activity introduces a way of measuring information content

Subject: Computer Science
English
Activities.Author: CS Unplugged
Activities.Description: This activity demonstrates how computers store text-based information

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Activities.Author: Code.org Unplugged
Activities.Description: Relate the concepts of algorithms to real-life activities

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: Code.org Unplugged
Activities.Additional Info: ** Many other code.org activities like these can be found in Curricula > CS Fundamentals
Activities.Description: Build critical thinking skills and excitement for programming

Subject: Social Studies
Language Arts
Activities.Author: Code Avengers
Activities.Description: Students sequency blocks to design the shield they want as part of a story

Activities.Subject: Social Studies
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators
Activities.Description: Create a flag to show what you know about the marchon washington

Activities.Subject: Social Studies
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators
Activities.Description: Code a digital museum to show what you know about online safety.

Subject: Social Studies
Language Arts
Activities.Author: CSEdWeek
Activities.Description: Learn about Grace Hopper and her role in computer history

Subject: Social Studies
Language Arts
Activities.Tech Required: iPad or iPhone w/ Hopscoth app
Activities.Author: Hopscotch
Description: Students will practice identifying narrative elements while bringing their favorite story
poem or historical event to life.

Activities.Subject: Social Studies
Activities.Author: iCompute
Activities.Description: This teacher-led lesson activity provides an opportunity to teach cross-curricular computing with history. Children research Ada Lovelace an important historical figure in computer science and the world's first computer programmer! They then use basic HTML to create a multimedia webpage showcasing their findings and skills as web masters.

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators (via HourOfCode)
Activities.Description: Code a conversation between two characters to show what you know about biographies

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators (via HourOfCode)
Activities.Description: Code a conversation between two characters to show what you know about biographies

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Kodable
Description: Choose your own adventure! Through a series of  If statements
students will alter the storyline and ending to a narrative they write.

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: CSFirst with Google
Description: Animate an ocean wave to create a setting
then tell a story that takes place on the high seas.

Subject: Language Arts
Art
Music
Activities.Author: Scratch
Description: Animate the letters of your name
initials
or a favorite word.

Subject: Language Arts
Math
Activities.Author: N2Y
Description: In these printable activities
students can help a little robot named Bitt Bott explore different landforms on Earth.

Subject: Language Arts
Math
Activities.Author: Trinket
Description: Choose from lessons
challenges
and tutorials about the Python programming language. Make turtle-based animations and solve puzzles
all while learning the basics of this powerful language. Activities range from block-based programming to real Python code
with activities appropriate for most age levels.

Subject: Computer Science
Language Arts
Activities.Author: iCompute
Activities.Description: Students begin to develop a journalistic style that considers the interest of the reader and presentation of information for an online news story.  Students use basic HTML and CSS to create and present an online news story about a fictional school robbery.

Activities.Activity Name: Writing and Coding: ELA Integration with Common Core Standards
Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Kodable
Activities.Description: Students will examine the concept of sequence in the context of reading and writing.

Activities.Subject: Computer Science
Activities.Author: Kodable
Description: Start by coding a  robot  together off screen
then learn about sequencing with the fuzzFamily!

Subject: Language Arts
Science
Activities.Author: Flocabulary
Description: In this lesson
students will explore events
a concept used in programming that allows programs to respond to specific stimuli
letting the user control the actions in the program

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Activities.Description: Students practice problem-solving with data compression puzzles. The idea with compression is that we use an algorithm to change the way the information is represented so that fewer characters are needed to store exactly the same information.

Subject: Language Arts
Art
Music
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Activities.Description: The class programs a card robot face to show different emotions one after another.

Activities.Subject: Language Arts
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Description: Students solve word puzzles as a way to develop logical thinking and pattern matching skills needed to enjoy both computing and maths
while practicing reading
writing and spelling.

Subject: Language Arts
Science
Activities.Author: Flocabulary
Additional Info: Students will build their literacy skills while diving into the field of robotics. They'll learn what a robot is and see examples of familiar robots used in daily life. They'll close-read short passages about robots
discuss tasks that robots are well suited for and finish the lesson by designing their own robot to solve a specific problem.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators
Activities.Description: Code a sorting game to show what you know about DNA.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Code Avengers
Activities.Description: Help Alex and Lonnie sort the sequences into order and debug by spotting and fixing the mistakes. Customize your own ocean scene and bring your characters to life by adding interactivity.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Washington University in St. Louis
Activities.Description: Watch a video to learn about computer science in meteorology and then learn how to program an incoming storm.

Subject: Science
Math
Activities.Author: CoSpaces.io
Activities.Description: Robot Rattle teaches students to operate a fully physically simulated robot with the help of a visual coding language by easily dragging & dropping blocks to write code instructions.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators
Activities.Description: Code a conversation to show what you know about food chains.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Tynker
Activities.Description: Program an interactive model of our Solar System. This STEM coding activity guides you through creating a simulation with planets orbiting the Sun.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Tynker
Activities.Description: Create an interactive ecological pyramid to track how energy flows through an ecosystem! This project comes with step-by-step instructions that guide you through creating an ecological pyramid for any ecosystem with animals and plants that glide to the proper location in the pyramid when clicked.

Activities.Activity Name: Make Interactive Science Models on Your iPad/iPhone!
Subject: Science
Math
Activities.Tech Required: iPad or iPhone w/ Hopscoth app
Activities.Author: Hopscotch
Activities.Description: This hour-long lesson plan uses the water cycle as an example for building an interactive computer model using an iPad-based kid's programming tool called Hopscotch. You can adapt it to simulate any dynamic system being studied. No prior experience required!

Subject: Science
Math
Activities.Author: Kodable
Description: If there is lightning
then thunder will follow! Students explore conditional statements in a hands-on science activity.

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: Codespeak Labs
Description: Through an illustrated children's story and worksheets
your students will learn the differences between hardware and software.

Subject: Science
Art
Math
Activities.Author: BlocksCAD
Description: Using BlocksCAD
a free online software designed to teach students coding and Computer Aided Design
students will design a 3D Robot. Using shapes
translate
and rotate blocks
students will be exposed to computational thinking to construct something they can 3D print!

Activities.Subject: Science
Activities.Author: iCompute
Activities.Description: Introducing Quick Response codes to children aged 3-5. Use tablets to scan QR codes and guess the mini-beast from a given habitat.

Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Author: code.org
Activities.Description: Let's use code to join Anna and Elsa as they explore the magic and beauty of ice. You will create snowflakes and patterns as you ice-skate and make a winter wonderland that you can then share with your friends!

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Brainpop Educators
Activities.Description: Code math problems that use multiplication

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Codemoji
Description: This course is designed to teach students the fundamentals of JavaScript objects. Students will learn the basic types of data that can be stored in variables
from their first boolean all the way to creating their own objects with multiple properties. The activity makes complex concepts easy to understand by using everyone's favourite food: Pizza!

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Code Avengers
Activities.Description: Join Ross at the Food Avengers restaurant. Use your computational thinking skills to help Ross solve problems and serve dinner to 8 excited kids.

Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Author: Kano Code
Description: Art and technology unite! With Kano's Street Art Hour of Code challenges
creative minds of all abilities will code with a paintbrush
making beautiful
unique artwork. Along the way
makers will learn computer science principles while using a real programming language in an intuitive and engaging way. With our teacher resources and guided content
everyone can get in on the fun.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: UCodemy
Description: We take you through an introduction to Itch

utilizing the Scratch visual programming language. This lesson provides a video and text directions for the code students need to add to get a ball bouncing zanily around the screen. Once students complete this activity there is an opportunity to explore with ideas for other changes and activities that can be made.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Codemoji
Description: Python Lab is an IOS based activity that teaches the basics of the programming language python. Users will learn about loops
arrays
booleans and much more.

Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Author: code.org
Activities.Description: Use block-based programming to draw cool pictures and designs with the Artist.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Tynker
Activities.Description: Code your own math game! Your character needs to escape the cave without getting hit by falling boulders. But the only way the character can run forward is by correctly answering math questions! You'll follow step-by-step instructions to program this fun multiplication quiz game.

Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Tech Required: iPad or iPhone w/ Hopscoth app
Activities.Author: Hopscotch
Description: Create your own version of the highly-engaging Geometry Jumper game in Hopscotch's open-ended programming environment! Along the way
you'll gain hands-on experience with concepts like sequence
loops
variables
and debugging. No prior experience is needed to complete or facilitate this activity; it includes a fun in-app video tutorial and a step-by-step facilitation guide.

Activities.Activity Name: Can I Make the Sun Set? w/ ScratchJr
Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Author: DevTech Research Group at Tufts
Description: Can I Make the Sun Set?  is an introductory activity meant for children in kindergarten through second grade with little to no programming experience to learn the basic features of ScratchJr and the elementary concepts of coding. Through this activity and continued time with ScratchJr
students will have the opportunity to think creatively
become storytellers
and improve upon mathematical reasoning and sequencing skills. Later
children can use the skills they have learned to create their own unique projects.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: BlocksCAD
Activities.Description: Students will examine pre-built bar graphs on BlocksCAD and interpret the data presented. They will expand and edit code and adjust existing variables to create their own graphs. Students will create new variables for the height of each bar and incorporate them into their code so that their entire bar graph is quickly customizable.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: BlocksCAD
Activities.Description: In this exploration students will set dinner tables by building and moving plates around using a first-quadrant 2D coordinate system. They will understand that translations from the origin define the x- and y-positions of a point in the plane. Students will create modules that allow them to quickly tell a “robot” where they would like a plate set so they can get out of doing the chore themselves!

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: BlocksCAD
Description: Students will run a birdhouse-building company
converting units
calculating dimensions
and using variables to scale their products.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Description: This activity is an example of creating an algorithm that is a simple sequence of instructions to do in order. It shows that if we have written down a solution to the problem in the form of an algorithm then we are able to do tours in future just by following the steps
without having to work it out from scratch again. Also if we write down the algorithm we can check that it definitely works by following it step by step on paper.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Description: This activity involves trying to solve a puzzle using two different representations. To start with it is fairly hard

but when the representation of the board and moves is changed it becomes really easy. Create graphs to represent the problem. See the power of using abstraction and how the choice of representation can make a problem much easier.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Vidcode
Description: In this exercise
you'll walk through with your students how programming with functions relates to what they already know about math by solving a math equation with programming.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Activities.Description: This introduces what an algorithms is and what a computer program is. It can also be used to explore human computer interaction and the importance of feedback and building a correct mental model.

Subject: Math
Art
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Description: Scenery in films is often computer generated. Ever wondered how they do it? Next time you find yourself drawing doodles
draw an algorithmic doodle and explore algorithms for drawing nature. The algorithms are recursive: that is they describe one step and then tell you just to draw the next step in the same way
following the algorithm from the start.

Activities.Subject: Math
Activities.Author: Teaching London Computing
Description: This trick illustrates how apparently simple things can be too complex for our brains to take in. An important design principle is that interfaces should be clear and simple
not cluttered. It also illustrates aspects of computational thinking such as simplifying the problem and the importance of understanding people.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Curricula.Description: Yearlong course of 6 units with daily lesson plans to provide an intro to computational thinking

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Curricula.Description: Guide to teaching program and many JS-based lessons

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: Contains 6 courses designed for K through 5th grade
respectively. Ranges from 12 to 20 lessons per course. Contains lesson overview for each course.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Curricula.Description: 14 lesson course for beginning readers in the Kindergarten age range. "Course A offers computer science curriculum for beginning readers around the kindergarten age range. Students will learn to program using commands like loops and events. The lessons featured in this course also teach students to collaborate with others meaningfully, investigate different problem-solving techniques, persist in the face of difficult tasks, and learn about internet safety. By the end of this course, students create their very own custom game or story from Play Lab that they can share."

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: Course B is a 13-lesson curriculum developed with first graders in mind. Tailored to a novice reading level
this course also assumes limited knowledge of shapes and numbers. At the moment
Course B closely parallels Course A
but provides more complex unplugged activities and more variety in puzzles. Students will learn the basics of programming
collaboration techniques
investigation and critical thinking skills
persistence in the face of difficulty
and internet safety. At the end of this course students will create their very own custom game from Play Lab that they can share with a link.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: Course C is a 16-lesson course developed for students in and around the second grade. It uses a limited understanding of shapes and elementary math concepts. Students will create programs with loops
events
and conditionals. They will translate their initials into binary
investigate different problem-solving techniques
and discuss how to respond to cyberbullying. By the end of the course
students will create interactive games that they can share. Each concept in Course C is taught from the beginning
graduating toward experiences that allow for growth and creativity to provide all students a rich and novel programming experience.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: Course D is a 19-lesson course created for students who read at roughly a third grade level. Angles and mathematical concepts are introduced with helpful videos and hints. The course begins with a review of the concepts found in Courses A
B
and C. This review helps introduce or refresh basic ideas such as repeat loops and events. Students will develop their understanding of algorithms
nested loops
while loops
conditionals
and events. Lessons on digital citizenship are also included. This course is crafted to build a strong foundation of basic concepts before opening up to a wide range of new and exciting topics.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: Course E is a 28-lesson course created with fourth grade students in mind

this course begins with a brief review of concepts previously taught in courses C and D. This introduction is intended to inspire beginners and remind the experts of the wonders of computer science. Students will practice coding with algorithms
loops
conditionals
and events before they are introduced to functions. At the end of the course
students will have the opportunity to create a capstone project that they can proudly share with peers and loved ones.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: The 28-lesson last course in CS Fundamentals was tailored to the needs of students in the fifth grade. In these lessons
students will create programs with different kinds of loops
events
functions
and conditionals. They will also investigate different problem-solving techniques and discuss societal impacts of computing and the internet. By the end of the curriculum
students create interactive stories and games that they can share with their friends and family.

Curricula.Subject: Computer Science
Description: CS Fundamentals Express combines the best of Courses A-F into a single condensed course. We recommend Courses A-F for most classrooms
but if your school only offers one computer science course or you want to have your students work through multiple courses in a single year
the Express course is a better choice.

Curricula.Subject: Social Studies
Description: This 3-part unit explores gender inequality and engages students in activities and discussions around different experiences and perspectives. Highlighting influential women in the history of tech
students learn about past pioneers and form their own opinions on equality in the tech field. At the end of the unit
students express their opinions in writing to effect change in their school community.

Subject: Computer Science
Math
Description: Keep the fun going! Use this project-based guide to facilitate a game design workshop
hackathon
or in-class series. Make: 1. Cross the Road 2. Geometry Jumper 3. Quiz Creator 4. Falling Bird 5. Subway Skaters 6. Escape the Room Each includes discussion questions
differentiation
and a video tutorial. Students can build off your instructions to customize their games. No prior experience required.

Subject: Math
Computer Science
Description: In a 3-part unit

students will connect math and programming to develop solutions for a restaurant's mobile ordering app. Dominic's Pizza restaurant is creating an algorithm for their new app and it's up to students to help calculate pizza costs. At the end of the unit
students will make and deliver their  pizza  after calculating the cost of the order.

Background Info.Description: Youtube videos for interested teachers in all subject areas
guidelines for computer science education at all grade levels
Outlines what students should gain from successful CS Ed
Highlights across-the-board benefits of CS Education
Developing a Pre-Service Teacher Training Program in Computational Thinking
